item.title: [TIKA-1623] Expose Translation Interface from Tika Server
item.description: Tika Server should expose the Tika Translate API. This will allow for easy use in downstream clients such as Tika-Python
item.summary: Expose Translation Interface from Tika Server

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment:
Any thoughts on how we'll allow setting of the service to use, and the license/api key for that? Via headers in the request? Via a properties file given to the Tika Server at startup? Via (new?) entries in the Tika Config + a custom Tika Config given to the Server at startup?

(I believe we can define translators via config, but not their api/license keys)

Hey Nick I was thinking we should think about a more common way to configure Translators. Not sure if I want to tackle that with this issue, but if you have time we are currently exploiting class loading and property files and so forth to store those secret keys and APIs and stuff. We could stick with that or introduce something like a ParseContext object or something like that for Translators. Thoughts?
I have a patch nearly ready for my first cut at this. Will upload soon.

To leverage:

  1. create a conf/org/apache/tika/language/translate folder
  2. create a translator.microsoft.properties file inside of that folder 
    translator.client-id=dummy-id
translator.client-secret=dummy-secret
  3. java -classpath ./conf:target/tika-server-1.9-SNAPSHOT.jar org.apache.tika.server.TikaServerCl

Going to commit - please improve opening up future issues.
Some things I see so far:

  • we need a better way to select Translation APIs
  • there are 2 categories - Network/API-based, and model-based (which can and probably also should be network based, but are based on ExternalTranslator)
  • we need to configure Translators better - currently ad-hoc and property files suck.
